G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, as this action involves a civil claim for damages arising in Worcester County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.raw_text: *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 716–717 (1977) (landlord liable when conduct or inaction substantially interferes with tenant’s use and enjoyment).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes an interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of her dwelling.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landlord is liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord’s conduct or failure to act causes substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment, even without an intent to do so. The court affirmed a finding that loud nighttime noise from a lounge, which the landlords introduced and had the power to control, constituted a constructive eviction and violation of quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that such conduct is an interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of her dwelling.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.550.proposition: Persistent rodent infestation constitutes a substantial interference with the quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.550, which requires a landlord to maintain the premises free from rodent infestation.

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.proposition: Persistent rodent infestation constitutes a substantial interference with the quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.550, which requires a landlord to maintain the premises free from rodent infestation.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that the tenant’s apartment was “infested with cockroaches and rodents” and clearly treats those conditions, along with other serious defects, as part of a breach of the warranty of habitability and a c. 93A violation. However, the case does not specifically analyze rodent infestation as a distinct ‘substantial interference with quiet enjoyment,’ nor does it cite or interpret 105 C.M.R. § 410.550 or articulate a standalone rule that persistent rodent infestation, by itself, constitutes a violation of that sanitary code section. Thus it is supportive by implication but not as direct authority for the exact proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: … (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents. … The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects by August 22, 1983. He also ordered Haddad to install a heating system by September 15, 1983, and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Persistent rodent infestation constitutes a substantial interference with the quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.550, which requires a landlord to maintain the premises free from rodent infestation.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the presence of mice among a list of sanitary code violations but does not analyze rodent infestation as a distinct legal issue, does not discuss 105 C.M.R. § 410.550, and does not state that rodent infestation in particular constitutes a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. The court’s discussion of habitability and sanitary code violations is general and treats most conditions as having minimal impact, without singling out rodents or setting a specific rule about them. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. ... The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks."

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to abate the infestation after notice violated G.L. c. 239, §8A and constitutes a retaliatory and negligent failure to maintain habitable conditions.

*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246\u.proposition: Defendant’s failure to abate the infestation after notice violated G.L. c. 239, §8A and constitutes a retaliatory and negligent failure to maintain habitable conditions.
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246\u.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaud concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act is the exclusive remedy for unpaid wages and whether common-law contract and quantum meruit claims are preempted, plus veil‑piercing issues. It does not address G.L. c. 239, § 8A, habitability, infestations, landlord‑tenant retaliation, or negligent failure to maintain premises. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about failure to abate an infestation constituting a retaliatory and negligent failure to maintain habitable conditions under § 8A.
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246\u.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant’s failure to abate the infestation after notice violated G.L. c. 239, §8A and constitutes a retaliatory and negligent failure to maintain habitable conditions.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case does interpret G.L. c. 239, § 8A and holds that a tenant may withhold/abate rent once the landlord has notice of conditions rendering the premises uninhabitable, regardless of the landlord’s fault or reasonable repair efforts. However, it expressly finds insufficient evidence that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith, and it does not treat the failure to abate as either ‘retaliatory’ or ‘negligent’ conduct—only as a strict-liability breach of the implied warranty of habitability. Thus, it does not support characterizing the conduct as retaliatory or negligent failure to maintain habitable conditions, even though it supports the rent-abatement aspect under § 8A.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent… When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations… In 1977, the Legislature struck this provision… The tenant may now withhold rent without considering whether the landlord is at fault or is taking reasonable steps to repair.”}

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts recognizes that a tenant need not vacate the premises to sustain a claim under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a tenant may sue for civil damages and injunctive relief under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it remands for an assessment of damages while the tenant remains in possession. However, the court does not explicitly state that the tenant “need not vacate the premises” to bring or sustain such a claim; that point is only implicit from the procedural posture. Because there is no express discussion of vacatur as a legal prerequisite, the case only indirectly, not directly, supports the proposition.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “It is further established that ‘a tenant may bring an action for civil damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, without first pursuing [that statute’s provisions for] criminal charges.’ Simon v. Solomon, supra at 100. On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction…; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14… The judgment is reversed and the case remanded… where the tenant may move for an assessment of damages…”}

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes a violation of the implied warranty of habitability, as interpreted in *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 200 (1973), which supports and informs the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s separate concurrence/dissent, not the majority. While he agrees that common-law rules must change and that statutory standards for habitability should inform tenants’ rights, he explicitly criticizes the majority’s broader, undefined ‘implied warranty of habitability’ and proposes a narrower approach tied to sanitary and housing codes. The quoted portion thus does not itself establish that the implied warranty of habitability ‘supports and informs’ the covenant of quiet enjoyment as the proposition states, and in fact distances itself from the majority’s implied-warranty formulation.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. … I dissent from the stated new rule for the further reason that the basis and scope of the landlord’s obligation thereunder are related to the court’s implication of a new and otherwise undefined warranty of fitness of the rented premises for human habitation.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover actual damages and costs under G.L. c. 186, §14, as well as reasonable attorney’s fees should counsel later appear.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts an entitlement to actual damages, costs, and attorney’s fees under G.L. c. 186, §14. Al‑Ziab holds the opposite in this context: a violation of the lead paint statute, without proof of at least negligent conduct and notice, does not establish a §14 violation, and thus does not justify an award of attorney’s fees under §14. The court vacated the fee award and ordered judgment for the landlords on the §14 count, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. … The award of attorney’s fees under G. L. c. 186, § 14, is vacated. … [T]he case is remanded to the Superior Court for entry of a new judgment on count two of the complaint in favor of the landlords.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: The landlord’s failure to maintain the Premises rodent-free also violates his duty under G.L. c. 111, §127A, which mandates compliance with the State Sanitary Code.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.proposition: Consistent with *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982), emotional distress and inconvenience damages are recoverable for breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “actual and consequential damages” for interference with quiet enjoyment to include personal injuries such as emotional distress. It explicitly states that consequential damages cover all reasonably foreseeable losses, “personal as well as economic,” and that Solomon’s emotional distress was within the scope of § 14. Although the separate $10,000 quiet-enjoyment award was vacated as duplicative, the opinion clearly recognizes emotional distress as a recoverable element of quiet enjoyment damages.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises… Generally, ‘actual damages’ are losses flowing directly from a wrongful act… ‘Consequential damages’ cover all losses that are reasonably foreseeable… The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case… Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14…”
